claim: Recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS have been shown to induce significantly higher levels of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against highly conserved regions of HA compared with egg-derived vaccines.

rejected_evidence.quote: 5. Treanor JJ, Schiff GM, Hayden FG, et al. Safety and immunogenicity of a baculovirus-expressed hemagglutinin influenza vaccine: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Vol. 297, pp. 1577-1582.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This reference is cited in the context of Flublok's clinical studies and specifically addresses the immunogenicity of a baculovirus-expressed (BEVS-produced) recombinant HA vaccine, supporting the claim that such vaccines induce strong antibody responses.

rejected_evidence.quote: 3. Keitel WA, Treanor JJ, El Sahly HM, et al. Comparative immunogenicity of recombinant influenza hemagglutinin (rHA) and trivalent inactivated vaccines (TIVs) among persons ≥65 years old. Vaccine 2009 Vol 28 pp 379-385.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This reference is included in the list of clinical studies and directly compares the immunogenicity of recombinant HA (produced using BEVS) with egg-derived trivalent inactivated vaccines, which is central to the claim.
